"In your anger do not sin": Do not let the sun go down while you are still angry, [27] and do not give the devil a foothold.      [NOTE: While believers may at times be legitimately angry (with righteous anger against sin; cf. John 2:13-16), they are not to sin. The way to prevent such sin is to "keep short accounts," dealing with the anger before the sun goes down. The reason is that the devil would like to intensify a Christian's righteous anger against sin, causing it to become sin itself. This then gives the devil a foothold (lit., "a place"), an opportunity for leading that Christian into further sin. Then anger begins to control the believer rather than the believer controlling his anger; The Bible Knowledge Commentary: An Exposition of the Scriptures by Dallas Seminary Faculty]

Why would God punish descendants for the sins of previous generations? First, it is important to note that this only applies to those that hate God. Secondly, the passage indicates that the punishment is passed on to future generations. God does not and cannot cause someone to sin. It is against his nature. If God does not cause the sin to continue, why does the punishment? The answer is that often sin tendencies are passed on to the next generation. Children who grow up in the presence of a repetitive ongoing sin often suffer in one of two ways. Either they form the same habits predisposing him or her to the same sin. Or, the sin appears to be normal as it is repeated constantly. Thus, the sin is duplicated in the next generation and God’s punishment continues.]

text: How much more, then, will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself unblemished to God, cleanse our consciences from acts that lead to death, so that we may serve the living God!    [NOTE on Hebrews 9:14: Vs. 14 the phrase “acts that lead to death”  means literally “dead works” which most likely refers to Levitical rituals. In the OT covenant sacrifices (animal and otherwise) served as a reminder of one’s sin. The sacrifices did not remove sin. It rendered the person ceremonially clean. Sin sacrifices were a reminder that God chose to not hold the unpaid sin against the person. The person remained unchanged spiritually. Unlike Jesus’ death on the cross. It paid fully for all sin and renders those who accept Jesus’ death as a payment for his or her sin completely free of the sin. There is a change in the spiritual status of the person. Most prefer to “earn” salvation rather than accept the gift. As such, there is a natural desire to continue with empty rituals that create ceremonial cleanliness. The phrase  “cleanse our consciences from acts that lead to death” is a statement that Jesus’ blood frees people of the need for ritual sacrifice. Those who accept this should have a clear conscience in ceasing the practice.]

topics: NOTE: At first blush it seems that James is promoting deeds as good works. However, if you look at each of the examples he provides, that is not what he is suggesting. He is saying that faith without acting in faith is dead. Abraham was willing to sacrifice Isaac – it was an act of faith that God would somehow preserve or restore Isaac as he was the seed of many nations. Rahab acted in faith believing the spies were God’s spies. By helping them she was serving God. She knew God was blessing Israel and wanted to share in that blessing. That is faith!

(quoted in Heb. 8:12)  No longer will a man teach his neighbor, or a man his brother, saying, 'Know the LORD,' because they will all know me, from the least of them to the greatest," declares the LORD. "For I will forgive their wickedness and will remember their sins no more.”      [NOTE: One of the grand features of the new covenant is that it affords a clear apprehension of God and his will by believers without human mediation. God will he known instinctively and his will performed spontaneously (cf. Isa 54:13; John 6:45). Experience of God will be direct, not dependent on external instruction. The knowledge spoken of is not theoretical knowledge transmitted by religious instruction. It is rather knowledge of God based on a heart experience of divine grace and imparted by the Holy Spirit with assurance that the believer has been received into the family of God through the forgiveness of sins (so KD). This knowledge does not militate against or render unnecessary religious instruction. (See the NT teaching concerning teachers in 1 Cor 12:28-29 and Eph 4:11-12.) There will be direct access to God for both Jew and Gentile. A vital feature of the old covenant was human mediation (cf. Exod 20:19). In the new one there is immediate access to God through Christ, our High Priest (cf. Heb 4:16; 10:19-22). The firsthand knowledge of God will be completely fulfilled in the coming kingdom (so Cunliffe-Jones). For the present it does not mean that every believer will he self-sufficient and independent of others. But it does indicate that all will have their own experience of God without resort to others. "The least of them" is very broad in meaning and includes "the least" in intellectual ability, in influence or position, in moral capacity—all are included in the comprehensive scope of the phrase. The Expositor's Bible Commentary, Volume 6: Isaiah, Jeremiah, Lamentations, Ezekiel.]

[21] This is how it will be with anyone who stores up things for himself but is not rich toward God."     [NOTE 1: This deals with the attitude of the rich.  God will not honor the rich who are concerned with storing riches up for themselves.  That leads to the person believing they are in total control of their own destiny and to a denial/forgetting that everything we have is a gift from God.  The rich must struggle to keep the balance of knowing that the wealth they have is a gift from God and to manage their wealth as a steward rather than managing it as an owner.  They must also struggle with not being overcome with greed for more wealth.  God requires us to give the first tenth of our wealth to Him to help us keep these balances in perspective.     NOTE 2: This is a negative example of true riches. It tells us that abundance of possessions is not a man’s life. Later in the chapter, Jesus instructs his listeners not to worry about physical needs. Instead, he instructs them to seek God’s kingdom (Luke 12:30-31). Those who do will receive all they need. True riches come from pursuing God’s kingdom first!]

text: "The Spirit of the Lord is on me, because he has anointed me to preach good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim freedom for the prisoners and recovery of sight for the blind, to release the oppressed,       [NOTE: ”Freedom for the prisoners” is a key piece to understand in this passage. Isaiah, and now Jesus, are saying God sent Jesus to free people from the power of sin. If one must be freed, it indicates the person is under the control of another power. In this instance, it is the power of darkness brought by Satan. Hence, the passage tells us that unbelievers are under the power of darkness where Satan rules. This is well put by the Lenski New Testament Commentary - The Interpretation of St. Luke's Gospel: “The image is not that of prisoners in jail but of prisoners of war who are dragged away into exile by the conqueror. So the devil holds men as captives with no hope of escape by any means of their own. And Jesus has the great commission to stand forth as a herald and to proclaim to them ἄφεσις, "release." This word is a correlative of captives and is thus used in the sense of release; but it is the standard term of the New Testament for the remission of sins, sending them away forever (compare 1:77). This herald-announcement is not an empty message but the authoritative, effective "release" itself which transfers these sighing captives of Satan into the liberty of the sons of God.”
topics: Satan Can Have Power Over People

Only one (Bib. Knowl. Cmy. Noted that Luke uniquely uses the Greek word, dynamis=spiritual ability, on several occasions. There is an interesting implication. If the power was present in this case, it implies there are other situations where the power was missing! There are two passages supporting this point: Matthew 13:58 and Mark 6:5-6. Faith must be present for Jesus to heal, it may be as small as a mustard seed (Matthew 17:20). This does not mean Jesus could not heal unless faith were present. It means Jesus chose not to heal when faith was absent. The Bible does not spell why this is the case. However, when Jesus healed it was meant to confirm that he was God’s son and to bring glory to God. In the absence of faith healing is nothing more than a curiosity, a spectacle, or freak show. topics: NOTE: The Psalm is written by David but recounts how God will work on David’s behalf. David was God’s anointed but he also pursued God relentlessly. God called him “a man after my own heart.” Being anointed and obedient multiplies the blessings. Those who are anointed but disobedient are blessed to a lesser extent. Solomon is an excellent example. God blessed him until he worshipped the God’s of his foreign wives. This is a sad but common pattern. Many start their ministry trusting and depending on God to work on his or her behalf. Success often causes people to forget that success is a result of pursuing God and depending on Him. Instead, he or she believes success depends solely on his or her work. Slowly they drift away from God. If this is not corrected, eventually he or she will fail morally or the ministry will begin to glorify the person rather than God. The goal should be to finish strong. A good start is nice, but a strong, God-centered finish is the real target.
